author: Paul Lamkin
title: Moto 360 2 No-Show Paves Way For IFA Reveal
text:
The Moto 360 sequel is expected to launch soon (Motorola)
There was much to get excited about at the big Motorola launch event, with a trio of new smartphones being unveiled by the Lenovo-owned brand.
However, those hoping to see some wearable action were left disappointed, with the much-rumoured Moto 360 smartwatch sequel failing to materialise.
The no-show points towards a September launch for the Moto 360 2, with an IFA expo unveiling looking the most likely scenario now.
Here’s what we know about the Moto 360 2 so far…
It’s expected to launch this summer
The Moto 360 2 rumour-mill was kicked into top gear back in May when Lenovo’s chairman and chief executive, Yang Yuanqing told The Telegraph : “We have many new models in development with the Moto brands. So you may see in summer us launching some very exciting products, including phones and watches.”
We’ve seen the phones – the Moto X Play, the Moto X Style and the all-new Moto G were all revealed at the 28 July event – so that just leaves us wanting on the watches front.
We may have already seen it
If Motorola wanted to keep its Android Wear sequel a secret then it hasn’t really succeeded.
Could this be the Moto 360 2? (Weibo)
The photo above, posted by Yuanqing to the Chinese social network Weibo earlier this year, before being hastily deleted, purportedly shows off the Moto 360 2 in all of its glory.
The dead area will be no more
Adrienne Hayes, SVP of global marketing at Motorola, confirmed that the company’s next smartwatch will be smaller than the original, and it’s widely expected that the dead area at the bottom of the round display will, thankfully, be a thing of the past.
Another supposed leaked Moto 360 2 image (Weibo)
Another image to land on Weibo, pictured above, clearly shows that, like the Huawei Watch and the latest LG Android Wear devices, the display is a complete circular one.
Gleb Mishin, VP of Lenovo’s Eastern Europe division, revealed that the next-gen Moto 360 would have a “modified design” and would be “more beautiful and more like a clock.”
The Moto 360 will face some pretty stiff competition; check out our pick of the high-profile smartwatches still to come in 2015 .
Paul Lamkin is the editor-in-chief of Wareable .
